'''Imago Theatre''' is a theatre company based in [[Portland, Oregon]], United States.  Co-Artistic Directors, Carol Triffle and Jerry Mouawad, began collaborating in 1979 and founded Imago Theatre in 1982.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imagotheatre.com |title=Imago Theatre |publisher=Imago Theatre |date= |accessdate=2016-07-15}}</ref>

==History==
In addition to family shows that have toured nationally and internationally with extended appearances at the [[New Victory Theater]] in New York and [[American Repertory Theater]] in Boston, the company has produced dozens of experimental original works locally.  Their work is influenced by [[Jacques Lecoq]]. Triffle studied with Lecoq at [[L'École Internationale de Théâtre Jacques Lecoq]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ecole-jacqueslecoq.com/en/school_en-000001.html |title=The School - School |publisher=Ecole Jacques Lecoq |date=1956-12-05 |accessdate=2020-01-16}}</ref> and Mouawad studied Lecoq-based theatre at the Hayes-Marshall School of Theatre Arts.  The company is known for creating productions that "combine absurdity with the universal themes of humanity both humorous and poignant and told in a most unique way."  <ref>{{cite web|first=Nancy |last=Tannler |url=https://www.southeastexaminer.com/2018/05/the-creatives-of-imago-theatre/|title=The Creatives of Imago Theatre |work=Southeast Examiner |date=2019-05-01|accessdate=2020-01-17}}</ref>

In 1992, Imago converted a 1924 historic masonic lodge in Southeast Portland to a 200-seat theatre, while using the upper level as a workshop and development space.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pdxmonthly.com/arts-and-culture/2014/05/5-portland-artists-with-international-fans-may-2014/ |title=5 Portland Arts Ensembles With Global Followings |work=[[Portland Monthly]] |date=2014-05-01 |accessdate=2020-01-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wweek.com/arts/2016/07/12/after-24-years-an-east-burnside-theater-is-closing/ |title=East Burnside Theater is Closing After 24 Years |work=[[Willamette Week]] |date=2016-07-06 |accessdate=2016-07-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Scott |first=Aaron |url=http://www.opb.org/artsandlife/article/portland-imago-theatre-sell-historic-building/#.V4XSYc389Es.mailto |title=Imago Theatre To Sell Its Historic Portland Building Amid Rising Costs . Arts & Life |publisher=[[Oregon Public Broadcasting]] |date= |accessdate=2016-07-15}}</ref>

3371360.title: B in the Mix: The Remixes

revisions.*:
{{short description|2005 remix album by Britney Spears}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox album | name = B in the Mix: The Remixes | type = remix | artist = [[Britney Spears]] | cover = BintheMix.jpg | border = yes | alt = Image of a woman dancing in a grey tone. There is a grey aura behind her, and she is standing in front of a black background. A giant butterly extends in her bust. The words "Britney B Spears" are written above in white letters. At the height of her waist, the words "in the mix The Remixes" are written in smaller grey letters. | caption = North American edition cover artwork; international cover artwork features Spears behind the butterfly. | released = November 22, 2005 | recorded = 1998–2005 | studio = [[Zomba Group of Companies|Battery Studios]]
(New York City, New York) | genre = *[[Electronic music|Electronic]] *[[dance-pop]] *[[House music|house]]{{cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/Britney-Spears-B-In-The-Mix-The-Remixes/release/569903|title=Britney Spears – B In The Mix – The Remixes (CD, Comp, Copy Prot.) at Discogs|work=Discogs|date=November 22, 2005|access-date=October 11, 2017}} *[[Trance music|trance]] | length = 54:01 | label = [[Jive Records|Jive]] | producer = *[[Dave Audé]] *[[Bloodshy & Avant]] *[[Peter Rauhofer]] *[[Tricky Stewart|Trixter]] *Penelope Magnet *[[Justice (band)|Justice]] *[[Jimmy Harry]] *[[Sheppard Solomon|Shep Solomon]] *Bill Hamel *Barry Jamieson *[[Mark Taylor (music producer)|Mark Taylor]] *[[Stuart Price]] *[[The Neptunes]] *[[Junkie XL]] *[[Guy Sigsworth]] *Valentin *[[Moby]] *[[Jason Nevins]] *[[Nick Fiorucci]] *Taras Harkavyi *[[Max Martin]] *[[Rami Yacoub|Rami]] *Davidson Ospina *[[Robert John "Mutt" Lange]] *[[Hex Hector]] *Dezrok *Mac Quayle *Jeff Taylor | prev_title = [[#Key Cuts from Remixed|Key Cuts from Remixed]] | prev_year = 2005 | next_title = [[Blackout (Britney Spears album)|Blackout]] | next_year = 2007 }} '''''B in the Mix: The Remixes''''' is the first [[remix album]] by American singer [[Britney Spears]]. It was released on November 22, 2005 through [[Jive Records]]. The album contains remixes of tracks from her first four studio albums—''[[...Baby One More Time (album)|...Baby One More Time]]'' (1999), ''[[Oops!... I Did It Again (album)|Oops!... I Did It Again]]'' (2000), ''[[Britney (album)|Britney]]'' (2001) and ''[[In the Zone]]'' (2003)—a remix of "[[Someday (I Will Understand)]]", and a remix of a new track "[[And Then We Kiss]]". The remixes were done by DJs such as [[Peter Rauhofer]] and [[Stuart Price]]. The music was influenced by various genres of [[electronic music]], such as [[Ambient music|ambient]] and [[Techno music|techno]]. ''B in the Mix: The Remixes'' received mixed reviews from [[music critics]]. Some reviewers called it a good remix compilation, while others argued that the album was conceived as a product and also criticized what they perceived as weak vocals. ''B in the Mix: The Remixes'' peaked at number four on the US [[Dance/Electronic Albums]] and at number one-hundred-and-thirty-four on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]. It received minimal promotion compared to Spears' previous albums. The [[Junkie XL]] remix of "And Then We Kiss" was released as a promotional single from the album in Australia and New Zealand on October 31, 2005. A [[B in the Mix: The Remixes Vol. 2|second volume of this album]] was released in 2011. ==Background== Jive Records originally planned to release a Japan-exclusive remix album ''Greatest Remixes'' in early 2005, but plans fell through.{{Cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Greatest-Remixes-Britney-Spears/dp/B00092QSN2|title = Greatest Remixes|website = Amazon}} On September 28, 2005, Jive Records announced through a press release that Spears would release a remix album titled ''Remixed''.{{cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/britney-junkie-xl-team-up-on-remix-disc-61297/ |title= Britney, Junkie XL Team Up On Remix Disc|date=September 28, 2005|access-date=April 27, 2022|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]}} However, on November 8, 2005, it was reported by Jennifer Vineyard of [[MTV]] that the album was actually titled ''B in the Mix: The Remixes'', and was going to be released on November 22, 2005. The album includes songs from her previous albums remixed by [[disc jockey|DJs]] such as [[Peter Rauhofer]] and [[Stuart Price]]. Price had previously remixed "Breathe on Me" from ''[[In the Zone]]'' for a limited edition bonus disc of Spears' first [[greatest hits album]] ''[[Greatest Hits: My Prerogative]]'' (2004). ''B in the Mix: The Remixes'' also includes a remix of one previously unreleased song, "And Then We Kiss";{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1512630/surprise-britneys-releasing-an-album-in-just-two-weeks/|title=Surprise: Britney's Releasing An Album In Just Two Weeks|last=Vineyard|first=Jennifer|website=[[MTV]]|date=November 8, 2005|access-date=April 26, 2022}} the song had previously been set to be included on a [[Britney & Kevin: Chaotic (EP)|bonus disc]] of her DVD for ''[[Britney & Kevin: Chaotic]]'' (2005), but was left out in favor of another song, "Over to You Now".{{cite news|url=http://www.rcalabelgroup.co.uk/artist_spotlight/britney_spears/1145/15/|title= Britney Spears. Chaotic – DVD out October 31st |date=October 18, 2005|access-date=January 4, 2010|publisher=[[RCA/JIVE Label Group]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071123063932/http://www.rcalabelgroup.co.uk/artist_spotlight/britney_spears/1145/15/|archive-date=November 23, 2007}} ==Music and lyrics== {{Listen |pos=right |filename=Britney Spears - And Then We Kiss.ogg |title="And Then We Kiss" |description=A 26-second sample of the song's chorus, where Spears sings over a euro-trance melody. |format=[[Ogg]] }} The Bill Hamel remix of "Touch of My Hand" is a [[trance music|trance]] track with elements of [[ambient music|ambient]]. Spears' voice has been described as "chopped up into skittering syllables and [...] becomes part of the beat". The album's fourth track, the [[Stuart Price|Jacques Lu Cont]]'s Thin White Duke Mix of "Breathe on Me" slows the beat from the original track making the song "darker and dirtier". The remix style was compared to songs by [[Kylie Minogue]] and [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]]. [[Dave Audé]] Slave Driver Mix of "[[I'm a Slave 4 U]]" consists of a guitar track and "quirky analog touches", according to Kurt Kirton of [[Dotdash|About.com]]. "And Then We Kiss" contains influences of [[Eurodance|euro-trance]], [[techno]] and usage of [[synthesizers]]. The song blends [[dance-rock]] guitars and symphonic strings and closes with an orchestral overtone. Its lyrics talk about a kiss and the different sensations that the protagonist experiences, including trembling, crying and moaning. At the beginning she sings the lines "Lying alone / touching my skin" which suggest that the whole song may actually be a fantasy. The album's seventh track, the Valentin remix of "[[Everytime]]" contains a serious [[groove (music)|groove]] and pounding [[Percussion instrument|percussion]], with usage of synthesizers. The [[Jason Nevins]] remix of "Early Mornin'" is considered the only [[Hip hop music|hip hop]] song of ''B in the Mix: The Remixes''. ==Title and artwork== The album was originally titled ''Remixed'', however, it was later revealed it would be titled ''B in the Mix: The Remixes''. ''B in the Mix: The Remixes'' had two cover artworks: North American one and international one. On the North American edition, Spears doesn't appear on the cover artwork; there is a red butterfly instead. Vineyard noted this, stating: "[the album] is being marketed in a more underground way than usually associated with a superstar act". On the international edition cover artwork, a [[black-and-white]] image of Spears appears behind the butterfly. ==Release and promotion== ''B in the Mix: The Remixes'' received little promotion compared to Spears' standards. A promotional [[extended play]] titled ''Key Cuts from Remixed'' with several remixes from the album was released in September 2005.{{cite web|url=http://www.ultratop.be/en/showitem.asp?interpret=Britney+Spears&titel=Key+Cuts+From+Remixed&cat=s |title=Britney Spears – Key Cuts from Remixed (song) |year=2005 |publisher=Ultratop. Hung Medien |access-date=April 17, 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025041941/http://www.ultratop.be/en/showitem.asp?interpret=Britney+Spears&titel=Key+Cuts+From+Remixed&cat=s |archive-date=October 25, 2012 }} A contest was launched on Spears' paid fan site for those who pre-ordered the album. The winner received a copy of ''[[Britney & Kevin: Chaotic (EP)|Britney & Kevin: Chaotic]]'', a bottle of Spears' fragrance ''[[Fantasy (fragrance)|Fantasy]]'' with an additional lotion and make-up kit, and a personalized autographed picture of Spears.{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1513471/for-the-record-quick-news-on-britney-spears-christina-aguilera-young-buck-lindsay-lohan-50-cent-more/|title=For The Record: Quick News On Britney Spears, Christina Aguilera, Young Buck, Lindsay Lohan, 50 Cent & More|website=MTV|access-date=November 8, 2005|date=April 27, 2022}} On November 22, 2005, the day the album was released, a release party was held at an unspecified [[nightclub]] in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], organized by Spears' management and the webmaster of the fansite WorldOfBritney.com. It was a limited event to five hundred people, including members of the fansite or her official fan club. Spears commented: "I just wanted to say that I love the idea of all my fans getting together to celebrate the release of my new album. I was happy to help! I hope you have a great night out at the club and dance all night long!".{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1513681/for-the-record-quick-news-on-christina-aguilera-britney-spears-john-legend-50-cent-harry-potter-korn-more/|title=For The Record: Quick News On Christina Aguilera, Britney Spears, John Legend, 50 Cent, Harry Potter, Korn & More|website=MTV|access-date=April 27, 2022|date=November 14, 2005}} Before being included on ''B in the Mix: The Remixes'', "[[And Then We Kiss]]" was initially produced by [[Mark Taylor (producer)|Mark Taylor]] for Spears' fourth studio album, ''[[In the Zone]]'' (2003). It failed to be included on the album;{{cite web|url=http://www.muumuse.com/2011/09/britney-spears-and-then-we-kiss-original-version-leaks.html/|title=Daily B: The Original Version of 'And Then We Kiss' Surfaces|last=Stern|first=Bradley|date=September 2, 2011|publisher=Muumuse|access-date=September 5, 2011}} however, after being remixed by [[Junkie XL]] for ''B in the Mix: The Remixes'', it was released as promotional single from the album in Australia and New Zealand on October 31, 2005.{{cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/au/album/and-then-we-kiss-single/264787055 |title=And Then We Kiss – Single by Britney Spears |publisher=Apple Music |date=October 31, 2005 |access-date=April 27, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121111222604/https://itunes.apple.com/au/album/and-then-we-kiss-single/id264787055 |archive-date=November 11, 2012 }}{{cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/nz/album/and-then-we-kiss-single/264787055 |title=And Then We Kiss – Single by Britney Spears |publisher=Apple Music |date=October 31, 2005 |access-date=April 27, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121113202128/https://itunes.apple.com/nz/album/and-then-we-kiss-single/id264787055 |archive-date=November 13, 2012 }} A promotional [[12-inch single]] featuring a new version of the remix was also released.{{cite AV media notes|title=And Then We Kiss|others=Britney Spears|date=2005|type=12" Vinyl liner notes|publisher=JIVE Records|id=82876 76466 1}} The remix received mostly positive reviews from [[music critics]], with some noticing its potential to be a radio or club hit. "And Then We Kiss" failed to appear on any major charts, however, it peaked at number fifteen on the US [[Hot Dance Airplay]].{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/charts/chart-search-results/singles/3066099|title=Hot Dance Airplay|date=May 6, 2006|access-date=June 12, 2011|work=Billboard}} The version of the song produced by Taylor remained unreleased for years, until a new mix of the song labelled as the original version leaked online on September 2, 2011. After suggestions that it might be fake, Taylor confirmed its authenticity to Bradley Stern of Muumuse.com on September 5, 2011. ==Critical reception== {{Album ratings | AOTY = 53/100{{cite web |title=Britney Spears – ''B in the Mix: The Remixes'' |url=https://www.albumoftheyear.org/album/22413-britney-spears-b-in-the-mix-the-remixes.php|publisher=Album of the Year |access-date=30 September 2020 }} | rev1 = [[About.com]] | rev1Score = {{Rating|3|5}} | rev2 = [[AllMusic]] | rev2Score = {{Rating|2.5|5}} | rev3 = ''[[Bay Area Reporter]]'' | rev3Score = unfavorable | rev4 = ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' | rev4Score = C | rev5 = [[IGN]] | rev5Score = (6.9/10) | rev6 = [[MTV]] | rev6Score = favorable | rev7 = ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' | rev7Score = {{Rating|3|5}} | rev8 = ''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'' | rev8Score = mixed{{cite web|url=http://www.dentonrc.com/sharedcontent/dws/ent/stories/DN-britneyalbums_1103gl.ART.State.Edition1.4209e2e.html|archive-url=http://archive.today/3ALjO|url-status=dead|archive-date=June 9, 2007|title=Britney Spears' recordings find art imitating life|last=Daniel|first=Mike|date=November 6, 2007|access-date=September 10, 2011|work=[[Denton Record-Chronicle]]|publisher=[[A. H. Belo Corporation]]}} }} ''B in the Mix: The Remixes'' received mixed reviews from music critics. Kurt Kirton of [[About.com]] highlighted the remixes of "[[Everytime (Britney Spears song)|Everytime]]" and "[[Don't Let Me Be the Last to Know]]", adding that the album would be better if it included more tracks. He summarized his review saying, "this is a decent release that should please any Britney fan and most club music fanatics".{{cite news|url=http://dancemusic.about.com/od/reviews/fr/BritneyIntheMix.htm|title=Britney Spears – B In the Mix (The Remixes)|last=Kirton|first=Kurt|website=[[About.com]]|year=2005|access-date=April 17, 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120305222451/http://dancemusic.about.com/od/reviews/fr/BritneyIntheMix.htm|archive-date=March 5, 2012|df=mdy-all}} Barry Walters of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' said the album was "even more redundant" than ''Greatest Hits: My Prerogative'', but added that with the exception of "[[Toxic (song)|Toxic]]", "just about every original track is bettered here".{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-album-reviews/b-in-the-mix-the-remixes-deluxe-version-247009/|title=Rolling Stone : B In The Mix, The Remixes (Deluxe Version) : Review|date=November 28, 2005|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|publisher=[[Jann Wenner]]| access-date=April 27, 2022|last=Walters|first=Barry|issn=0035-791X}} Spence D. of [[IGN]] said: "If you had the choice to purchase only one Britney Spears' album, then this would be the one to spend your money on."{{cite web|url=https://www.ign.com/articles/2005/11/23/britney-spears-b-in-the-mix-the-remixes |title=Britney Spears B in the Mix: The Remixes |date=November 23, 2005 |access-date=April 27, 2022|last=D. |first=Spence |website=[[IGN]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208123128/http://music.ign.com/articles/670/670585p1.html |archive-date=February 8, 2012 }} Stephen Thomas Erlewine of [[AllMusic]] commented that "''B in the Mix'' doesn't exactly erase the impression that Spears isn't in tune with her recording career". He also stated that on tracks such as "Toxic", "her flaws stand out just a bit too much [...] the instrumental hooks have been removed from the record, leaving Spears to carry the day—which she can't really do. [...] Overall this album sounds and feels like what it really is: a piece of product."{{cite news|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r804463/review|pure_url=yes}}|title=allmusic ((( B in the Mix: The Remixes > Overview )))|last=Erlewine|first=Stephen Thomas|publisher=[[AllMusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]]|year=2005|access-date=April 17, 2010}} [[MTV]] writer Bradley Stern praised the album, saying it "featured loads of excellent remixes stretching from "[[...Baby One More Time (song)|...Baby One More Time]]" to "Toxic", but nothing shined quite as bright as the album's undeniable highlight: "[[And Then We Kiss]]" ([[Junkie XL]] Remix)."{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/2299247/britney-spears-remixes/|title=The 5 Best Britney Spears Remixes Ever!|date=October 10, 2011|last=Stern|first=Bradley|access-date=April 27, 2022|website=[[MTV]]}} [[Gregg Shapiro]] of the ''[[Bay Area Reporter]]'' gave the album a mostly negative review, calling it "hazardous waste". He also noted that Spears's voice was "reedy, cold and mechanical" when stripped from the original mixes. However, he highlighted two tracks, saying: "Spears comes closest to achieving dance-diva status on the Valentin remix of "Everytime", while the Davidson Ospina 2005 remix of "Baby One More Time" elevates the original bubblegum track to club classic."{{cite news|url=http://www.ebar.com/arts/art_article.php?sec=music&article=100|title=Movers and shakers|last=Shapiro|first=Gregg|work=[[Bay Area Reporter]]|publisher=Benro Enterprises, Inc.|date=February 2, 2006|access-date=April 17, 2010}} Mike Daniel of ''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'' called the [[Justice (band)|Justice]] remix of "[[Me Against the Music]]" the best track of the album, but said it "has the feel of a hastily executed stopgap measure with almost no marketing-related thought behind it except to fulfill the once-every-two-years release cycle that's been established for Britney material." ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' writer Leah Greenblatt noted the remixes "amps already-aggressive singles like "Toxic" and "Me Against the Music" to brain-popping levels of synth spiraling", and transforms "sad-eyed slow jams like "Everytime" and "Don't Let Me Be the Last to Know" into [[Hi-NRG]] bursts. This party is BYORB (Bring Your Own [[Red Bull]]); without it, you might not be able to keep up."{{cite web|first=Leah |last=Greenblatt |url=https://ew.com/article/2005/12/12/be-mix-remixes/|title=B in the Mix: The Remixes (2005)|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=December 12, 2005|access-date=April 27, 2022}} ==Commercial performance== In the United States, ''B in the Mix: The Remixes'' debuted at number 134 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], selling 14,000 copies in its first week. It spent eleven weeks on the chart overall.{{cite web|last=Jenison|first=David|title= System "Hypnotizes" Charts |publisher=[[Yahoo! Music]]| date=November 30, 2005 | url=http://ca.music.yahoo.com/read/news/26490299 | access-date=May 9, 2010}} The album also peaked at number four on the US [[Top Dance/Electronic Albums]], making it the first top four peak on the chart that had over 10,000 units sold since July 2002.{{cite magazine |year=2006 |title=Winers and Losers of 2005 |magazine=Billboard |volume=117 |issue=50 |pages=72 |issn=0006-2510 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZxMEAAAAMBAJ&q=%22b+in+the+mix%3A+the+remixes%22&pg=PA53 |access-date= September 23, 2011}} The album spent a total of 21 weeks on the chart.{{cite news|title=B in the Mix: The Remixes – Britney Spears |work=Billboard |year=2005 |url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=britney spears|chart=all}} |access-date=May 1, 2010 |url-status=dead }} According to [[Nielsen SoundScan]], ''B in the Mix: The Remixes'' has sold over 131,000 copies in the United States.{{cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/ask-billboard-spears-lovatos-x-cellent-sales-updated-485947/|title=Evanescence, Lauren Alaina Targeting Billboard 200 Top 10|last=Caulfield|first=Keith|work=Billboard|access-date=October 14, 2011|date=October 14, 2011}} The album also debuted on [[Ultratop 50|Ultratop Wallonia]] in Belgium at number 99 on the chart dated December 17, 2005,{{cite web|url=https://www.ultratop.be/fr/album/6323/Britney-Spears-B-In-The-Mix-The-Remixes |title=Britney Spears – B in the Mix: The Remixes (album) |access-date=May 1, 2010 |publisher=[[Ultratop]]. Hung Medien |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121112173550/http://www.ultratop.be/fr/showitem.asp?interpret=Britney+Spears&titel=B+In+The+Mix+-+The+Remixes&cat=a |archive-date=November 12, 2012 }} and also debuted at number 59 on the [[FIMI|Italian Albums Chart]] on the chart dated November 25, 2005.{{cite web|url=http://www.fimi.it/classifiche_result_artisti.php?anno=2005&mese=11&id=140 |title=Britney Spears – B in the Mix: The Remixes |access-date=December 14, 2010 |publisher=[[FIMI]] |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120404144150/http://www.fimi.it/classifiche_result_artisti.php?anno=2005&mese=11&id=140 |archive-date=April 4, 2012 }} The album peaked at number 25 on [[Oricon Albums Chart]] in Japan, where it spent eight weeks on the chart.{{cite web|url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/music/release/d/624725/1/|title=Britney Spears – B in the Mix: The Remixes album information |access-date=December 14, 2010|publisher=[[Oricon]]}} ==Track listing== {{Track listing | headline = ''B in the Mix: The Remixes'' {{nobold|– Standard edition}} | extra_column = Producer(s) | total_length = 54:01 | title1 = [[Toxic (song)|Toxic]] | note1 = Peter Rauhofer Reconstruction Mix Edit | writer1 = {{flat list| *[[Cathy Dennis]] *[[Bloodshy & Avant|Christian Karlsson]] *[[Bloodshy & Avant|Pontus Winnberg]] *[[Henrik Jonback]] }} | extra1 = {{flat list| *[[Bloodshy & Avant]] *[[Peter Rauhofer]]{{ref|a|[a]}} }} | length1 = 6:46 | title2 = [[Me Against the Music]] | note2 = featuring [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]]) (Justice Remix | writer2 = {{flat list| *[[Britney Spears]] *Madonna *[[Tricky Stewart|C. '''Russia''' participated in the '''Eurovision Song Contest 2000''' in [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]]. The Russian entry was selected internally by the Russian broadcaster [[Channel One Russia|Russian Public Television]] (ORT). [[Alsou]] represented Russia with the song "Solo", which placed 2nd and scored 155 points at the contest.<ref name=finalresults>{{cite web|title=Eurovision Song Contest 2000|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=315#Participants|work=Eurovision.tv|access-date=11 July 2013}}</ref>

==Before Eurovision==
For the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1998|1998 Contest]], Russia was relegated from competing due to a poor average score from the preceding contests. In [[Eurovision Song Contest 1999|1999]], Russia was ineligible to compete because of the failure to air the 1998 Contest on television, which was a requirement for future participation.<ref>{{cite web|first=Andy|last=Mikheev|title=Eurovision 1998|url=http://russia.esckaz.com/1998e.htm|work=ESCKaz|access-date=11 July 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|first=Andy|last=Mikheev|title=Eurovision 1999|url=http://russia.esckaz.com/1999e.htm|work=ESCKaz|access-date=11 July 2013}}</ref>

In 1999, ORT announced that a national final would take place on 19 February 2000 to select the Russian entry for the Eurovision Song Contest 2000 and opened a submission period for interested artists and composers to submit their entries until 15 February 2000.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ng.ru/tv/1999-12-18/12_bytheway.html|title=По пути / Телевидение / Независимая газета}}</ref> A jury panel headed by Konstantin Ernst was to evaluate the received submissions and select entries for the contest, however, due to financial problems, ORT decided to select a participant internally among the submitted entries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://old.telesputnik.ru/archive/52/article/30.html|title = Журнал Теле-Спутник}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kommersant.ru/doc/147905|title=Алсу спасла Россию|date=16 May 2000}}</ref> 

Ultimately, [[Alsou]] was internally selected with Russia's first English language contest song, "Solo". The entry was also the first foreign collaboration to represent Russia, as the composers, [[Andrew Lane (record producer)|Andrew Lane]] and Brandon Barnes, were both [[Americans|American]].<ref name=RUS>{{cite web|first=Andy|last=Mikheev|title=Eurovision 1997 Alsou|url=http://russia.esckaz.com/2000e.htm|work=ESCKaz|access-date=11 July 2013}}</ref>

==At Eurovision==
Russia performed 9th at the 2000 Contest, following [[Norway in the Eurovision Song Contest 2000|Norway]] and preceding [[Belgium in the Eurovision Song Contest 2000|Belgium]]. After the voting concluded, Russia scored 155 points, including 4 Sets of 12 Points, from Croatia, Cyprus, Malta and Romania; and placed 2nd.<ref>{{cite web |title=Final of Stockholm 2000 |url=https://eurovision.tv/event/stockholm-2000/final |publisher=European Broadcasting Union |access-date=10 April 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210410194017/https://eurovision.tv/event/stockholm-2000/final |archive-date=10 April 2021 |url-status=live}}</ref>

The voting spokesperson for Russia was Zhanna Agalakova.<ref name=RUS/>

The military budget or defence budget of [[India]] is the portion of the overall budget of [[Union budget of India]] that is allocated for the funding of the [[Indian Armed Forces]]. The military budget finances employee salaries and training costs, maintenance of equipment and facilities, support of new or ongoing operations, and development and procurement of new technologies, weapons, equipment, and vehicles.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Navlakha|first=Gautam|date=1999|title=Defence Spending: Cost of Fighting Imaginary Enemies|url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/4407922|journal=Economic and Political Weekly|volume=34|issue=19|pages=1085–1088|issn=0012-9976}}</ref>

The [[Indian Army]] accounts for more than half of the total defence budget of India, with most of the expenditure going to the maintenance of cantonments, salaries and pensions, instead of critical arms and ammunition.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Defence Manufacturing in India|url=https://www.investindia.gov.in/sector/defence-manufacturing|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190103071510/https://www.investindia.gov.in/sector/defence-manufacturing|archive-date=3 January 2019|access-date=2021-07-09|website=www.investindia.gov.in|language=en}}</ref>

== Overview ==
India's defence budget includes allocation for the three defence services, army, navy and air force. It also includes allocation for the ordnance factories, research and development, and capital outlay. Additionally there are civil defence expenditures such as pensions. Unofficial expenditure includes expenses for four of the six [[Central Armed Police Forces]] responsible for border security. Space and atomic energy is funded separately.{{Sfn|Behera|2015|p=236-238}}

=== 2017–18 ===
[[Ministry of Finance (India)|Union Minister for Finance]] allocated {{INRConvert|359000|c|year=2017|lk=on}} of the [[2017 Union budget of India]] for development in the Indian armed forces, marking a raise of around 7% from the previous fiscal year.<ref>{{cite web|last=Behera|first=Laxman K|date=February 3, 2017|title=India's Defence Budget 2017-18:An Analysis|url=http://www.idsa.in/issuebrief/india-defence-budget-2017-18_lkbehera_030217|access-date=May 8, 2017|website=Institute for Defence Studies and Analyses|publisher=IDSA}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|date=2017-02-01|title=India's defence budget hiked 10pc to INR 2.74 trillion|language=en|newspaper=Dawn|agency=Reuters|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1312044/indias-defence-budget-hiked-10pc-to-inr-274-trillion|access-date=2017-02-01}}</ref> 

=== 2018–19 ===
In presenting the Defence Budget of 2018-19 Finance Minister allocated ₹4,04,365 crore (US$ 63 billion) for the [[Ministry of Defence (India)|Ministry of Defence]] (MOD).<ref>{{cite web|last=Gurung|first=Shaurya Karanbir|date=1 February 2018|title=Budget 2018: Defence sector gets a boost by 7.81%|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/defence/budget-2018-defence-sector-gets-a-boost-by-7-81/articleshow/62746419.cms|access-date=26 February 2018|website=Economic Times}}</ref> This translates into an increase of 5.66% over 2017-18 defence budget.

=== 2019–20 ===
As 2019 was an election year the [[National Democratic Alliance|NDA]] government presented an interim budget in place of a regular budget as per the general practice. In the interim budget an allocation of ₹4,31,011 crores (US$61.573 billion) was made.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Behera|first=Laxman Kumar|date=8 July 2019|title=India's Defence Budget 2019-20|url=https://idsa.in/issuebrief/indias-defence-budget-2019-20-lkbehera-080719|access-date=2020-02-14|website=|publisher=MP Institute for Defence Studies and Analyses}}</ref> On its re-election the NDA government kept the military budget unchanged. However the actual expenditure exceeded the estimated amount and final spending of defence for 2019-20 stood at ₹4,48,820 crores (US$62.71 Billion).<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last=Behera|first=Laxman Kumar|date=4 February 2020|title=India's Defence Budget 2020-21|url=https://idsa.in/issuebrief/india-def-budget-2020-21-lkbehera-040220|access-date=2020-02-14|publisher=MP Institute for Defence Studies and Analyses}}</ref> So there was an increase of around 10% with respect to previous budget.

=== 2020–21 ===
The allocation for defence during the fiscal year 2020-21 stood at (US$73.86 Billion).<ref name=":0" /> This amounted to an increase of just under 9%.{{Citation needed|date=February 2021}}

The allocation for defence during the fiscal year 2022 -23 stood at 76.88 billion dollar. Which is 3rd highest in the world after USA and china

'''UDP Unicorn''' is a [[Freeware|free]] and [[Open-source software|open source]] [[DoS attack]] software. The software attacks a computer's network connection by repeatedly sending [[User Datagram Protocol|UDP]] [[Packet (information technology)|packets]] with garbage data.

'''UDP Unicorn''' uses [[Winsock]] to create sockets and send UDP packets.

==Features==
* Multithreaded UDP flooder
* Port Scanner
* Active Connection Monitor
* Network Information - Public IP Address
* DNS
* ICMP send and receive (Ping)
* Target random ports and use random packet sizes
* User friendly GUI
* Pre-installed list of common protocols
* Ability to play music

'''Orazio Costa''' (6 August 1911 – 14 November 1999) was an Italian theatre pedagogist and director.

Born ''' Orazio Costa Giovangigli''' in Rome, Costa graduated at the [[Silvio d’Amico Academy of Dramatic Arts]] in 1937, and after being assistant director of [[Jacques Copeau]], in 1945 he started a long career as theatre director.<ref name=bio>{{cite news|last1=Rodolfo Di Giammarco|title=Orazio Costa, maestro di attori|url=http://ricerca.repubblica.it/repubblica/archivio/repubblica/1999/11/16/orazio-costa-maestro-di-attori.html?ref=search|accessdate=1 February 2015|newspaper=[[La Repubblica]]|date=16 November 1999}}</ref> He directed over 170 stage works.<ref name="bio"/> He founded and directed from 1948 to 1954 the Piccolo Teatro of the City of Rome.<ref name="bio"/>

Devoted to pedagogy, Costa was an acting teacher of the [[Silvio d’Amico Academy of Dramatic Arts|Silvio d’Amico Academy]] from 1944 to 1976.<ref name="bio"/> He then moved to [[Florence]], where he collaborated with the Teatro della Pergola and further developed his educational system founding the "Centro di avviamento all' espressione funzionante" ([[Italian language|Italian]] for "education center to functional expression"), active from 1979 to 1992.<ref name="bio"/> In 1996 Costa was honored with the title of Knight Grand Cross of the [[Order of Merit of the Italian Republic]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Onorificenze / conferimenti. Dettaglio decorato|url=http://www.quirinale.it/elementi/DettaglioOnorificenze.aspx?decorato=11515|website=[[Quirinale]]|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref>

In November 1991 he was accepted to [[Catholic University of Leuven (1834–1968)|Catholic University of Leuven]], earning his doctor's degree in January 1996.{{cite news|author1=Wen Jun ({{lang|zh|文俊}})|url=https://epaper.hubeidaily.net/pc/content/201911/23/content_7237.html |script-title=zh:中科院武汉分院孙和平、杨春和当选院士 |work=hubeidaily.net |date=23 November 2019 |accessdate=13 December 2019 |language=zh}} ==Career== In August 1980 he joined the Seismological Research Institute of [[China Seismological Bureau]], he remained there until October 1991. In January 1997 he became a researcher at the Institute of Geodesy and Geophysics, [[Chinese Academy of Sciences]] (CAS), where he was promoted to become deputy director in December 2000 and director in February 2005.
